markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

nola.com  (WEB - en-US)

A website affiliated with The Times-Picayune, a daily newspaper published in New Orleans, Louisiana, since 1837.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

NOLA.com and The Times-Picayune form the NOLA Media Group, a subsidiary of Advance Publications Inc., a privately held publisher of magazines and newspapers with holdings in cable television. The company’s nationwide holdings include Condé Nast Publications, Vanity Fair, Vogue and The New Yorker magazines, and newspapers including the Cleveland Plain-Dealer and The Star-Ledger in Newark, New Jersey.’

Content

NOLA.com covers local and national news, addressing a wide range of topics, including politics, health care, business, sports, and crime. The site also reports on culture, entertainment, food, weather, and local community events. Most of its stories are originally reported. Some content is reprinted from The Times-Picayune, while other content is unique to NOLA.com.

Credibility

NOLA.com does not list a code of ethics, but Mark Lorando, its editor-in-chief, wrote a blog post in 2017 that lays out many of the publication’s guiding principles. These include the importance of factual reporting, balanced opinions, community engagement, and the separation of fact and opinion.Times-Picayune won two Pulitzer prizes, for Public Service and for breaking news, in 2006 for its coverage of Hurricane Katrina. It won two other Pulitzers in 1997, for a series analyzing the global fish supply, and for Walt Handelsman’s editorial cartoons.

Transparency

NOLA.com credits photos and attributes information. Sponsored content and advertisements are clearly labeled and relegated to separate sections of the site. The website provides ample contact information for editors, managers, and content creators, although biographical information is limited. Articles on NOLA.com are updated with new information as it becomes available. Corrections are indicated with an editor’s note.

History

The newspaper was founded in 1837 as The Picayune (the Spanish name for a small coin). In 1914 it merged with rival paper The New Orleans Times-Democrat to form the Times-Picayune.

In 2012, the newspaper changed its publishing schedule from daily to three times per week but, faced with strong protests from residents of.New Orleans, relented. After trying several alternatives, including publishing a tabloid version of the paper, The Times-Picayune announced in 2014 that it would return to printing full broadsheet editions daily. They are reproduced online as e-editions.

Written by:
Grace Niewijk

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Joyce Purnick
